properties.name: Address of seizure: 4452 256th Street, Langley
properties.description: Posted by Vancouverpapers4452 256th Street, Langley, British ColumbiaAddress of seizure: 4452 256th Street, Langley. Seized asset: ,000 Cdn cash. Reason seized: The money is allegedly related to drug trafficking Named in lawsuit: Bradley Douglas Cook. Synopsis: Police on patrol noticed a Mercury Topaz with three people inside parked on a dimly lit street at night outside Coghlan Elementary school on Dec. 29, 2006. Police checked the vehicle and the driver voluntarily allowed police to check a backpack, which contained one sandwich bag with ,755 in bills and another with ,600, plus ,205 in Cook’s pocket. Also seized were some marijauana and a nine-millimetre round of ammunition. The money was forfeited.

properties.name: Address: 13475 - 57th Ave., Surrey
properties.description: Posted by Vancouverpapers13475 - 57th Ave., Surrey, British ColumbiaAddress: 13475 - 57th Ave., Surrey Seized items: The house and a Commodore 2660 Regal boat. Seized because: Part of the home was used for unlawful activity and the boat was allegedly bought with the proceeds of crime. Named in the lawsuit: David Dennis Peterson. Case synopsis: The home was under police suspicion by late 2002. It wasn’t until 2005 when police busted a marijuana operation in the garage. Police seized 300 pot plants and 46 pounds of “bud” in baggies. Peterson was charged with production of marijuana and pleaded guilty on Feb. 22 last year. He was sentenced to one year in jail. The property was bought for 23,000 in 2001 and now has an assessed value of 20,000. The boat was purchased for 0,000 by refinancing the house mortgage. The case went to court last April when the trial judge, in an interim ruling, allowed the house to be sold for not less than 20,000. The home was sold for 40,000 last June. The court ordered the proceeds to be placed in an interest-bearing trust account pending a final disposition.

properties.name: Address: Various locations in Vancouver, Richmond and Delta.
properties.description: Posted by Vancouverpapers 6480 Woodwards Rd., Richmond, B.C.Address: Various locations in Vancouver, Richmond and Delta. Seized assets: Police executed a search warrant on a safety deposit box and seized the contents, including 82,005 Cdn cash, a diamond ring appraised at 3,800, a Piaget watch purchased for 3,800,two gold chains, a jade pendant and other jewelry. Also seized were 0,000 US cash and another 4,410 in Canadian currency. Reason seized: The police allege the items in the safety deposit box were the “instruments of unlawful activity” and the cash allegedly was related to marijuana-growing operations. Named in the lawsuit: Tsz Wing Ching and Miu Wan (Vivian) Chan. Synopsis: An investigation was conducted by the Combined Forces Special Enforcement Unit. Between May 16, 2002 and March 14, 2003, police executed search warrants at a number of homes leased or owned by Chan, which were found to contain marijuana operations with a plants estimated to be worth .8 million at the street level. In the search at Chan’s home at 6480 Woodwards Rd. in Richmond, police seized 0,000 US from a canvas bag found in the back of a BMW. Another 4,410 Cdn cash was found in her purse. Chan was charged with cultivating marijuana and released on bail. On July 10, 2003 police executed a final search warrant on a safety deposit box jointly held by Ching and Chan, seizing the contents. The Canada Revenue Agency laid claim to 23,881 of the seized money for unpaid taxes and penalties, leaving 3,293 Cdn, plus the jewelry, which was forfeited. According to court documents, before the final seizure, Chan disposed of five and six properties she had bought for almost million between 2001 and 2003. Her current whereabouts are listed as unknown.

properties.name: Aug. 9, 2007
properties.description: Posted by VancouverpapersAddress: Fortune Happiness Restaurant, 654 E. Broadway Victims: eight; two died: Zachary Ferland, 19, of Prince Rupert and an unidentified 26-year-old man, both known to police. Global B.C. identified one of the surviving victims as Son Boui, a man in his late 20s. Assailant: unknown In what Vancouver police say is likely the worst mass shooting in the city\'s history, two masked gunmen burst into an east-side all-night Chinese restaurant early Thursday and shot eight people in front of horrified onlookers. At least two young men died and a third man was taken to hospital in critical condition, according to Vancouver police spokesman Const. Howard Chow. Five others were taken to hospital with less serious gunshot wounds. The shooting occurred around 4:30 a.m. at the Fortune Happiness Restaurant at 654 East Broadway, in Vancouver\'s Mount Pleasant district, leaving the restaurant shattered. No one has been charged with the crime.

properties.name: Feb. 24, 2007
properties.description: Posted by VancouverpapersAddress: Smithe and Seymour Victims: Two men in their 20s, unnamed Assailant: unknown At 5 a.m., two men in their 20s were wounded as they were leaving an after-hours nightclub near Smithe and Seymour in downtown Vancouver. One of the victims, a 24-year-old man who was shot in the head, was in critical condition in hospital. "If he lives, he will almost certainly be a paraplegic," Deputy Chief Doug LePard told a news conference.

properties.name: Feb. 25, 2007
properties.description: Posted by VancouverpapersAddress: 1900 block West 1st Avenue Victim: Syamac Gafary Asailant: unknown Syamac Gafary, a 32-year-old Burnaby resident with reported ties to Persian gangs, was shot to death in the 1900-block First Avenue at about 9:30 p.m. His record was extensive, with charges across the Lower Mainland dating from 1996 including uttering threats, theft, robbery, break and enter, drug possession, assault, assault causing bodily harm, assault with a weapon causing bodily harm, carrying a concealed weapon, unlawful confinement, and extortion. In most cases, the charges were stayed or Gafary was acquitted but he does have two 1998 convictions for theft and drug possession and another possession conviction in 2001.

properties.name: Feb. 27, 2007
properties.description: Posted by VancouverpapersAddress: 1800-block Triumph Street Victim: 64-year-old Richard Bezanson Assailant: unknown 64-year-old Richard Bezanson was found shot in broad daylight in the booze can he operated in the 1800-block of Triumph Street in east Vancouver. He was taken to hospital but died. There was no indication when the shooting occurred and no one reported hearing shots. Police said at the time that the address was known to them, but not Bezanson, who bought two houses side-by-side on the street in 2004. It was frequented by longshoremen and fisherman, as are other booze cans in the neighbourhood of Vancouver\'s industrial waterfront.

properties.name: Jan. 11, 2007
properties.description: Posted by VancouverpapersAddress: Shell Road and Westminster Highway, Richmond Victim: Kirk Robert Holifield (35) Kirk Robert Holifield, father of a nine-month-old girl, was shot "several times" near the intersection of Shell Road and Westminster Highway in Richmond at about 12:30 a.m. Holifield was found badly wounded, slumped over the wheel of his pickup truck. He died at Vancouver General Hospital. Police believe he was not the intended target, and it was a case of mistaken identity.

properties.name: Jan. 3, 2007
properties.description: Posted by VancouverpapersAddress: Dover Park (Dover Crescent), Richmond Victims: Niki Tajali (26), Vahid Mahanian (30), Sahand Askari (22). All were wounded and taken to hospital. 150 shots were fired by at least six gunmen gathered in Dover Park, Richmond. Police describe the three victims as "suspects first" in the wild-west-like shootout. Victims included Niki Tajali, 26, who owned a property overlooking the park. Tajali has had a series of run-ins with the law, including a 1998 conviction for assault with a weapon.

properties.name: Nov. 3, 2007
properties.description: Posted by VancouverpapersAddress: 3883 Cartier St., Vancouver Victim: Hong Chao (Raymond) Huang, 45 Assailant: unknown Forty-five-year-old Hong Chao (Raymond) Huang, a leader of the notorious Big Circle Boys gang, was believed to be a major player in the Canadian drug trade, involved in heroin, synthetic drugs, importation of precursor chemicals and more. A native of China, he is believed to have been in Canada for the past 10 years and has criminal ties to Toronto, the United States, Australia, Hong Kong and China. He was the subject of RCMP investigations when he was gunned down by a shooter who was waiting when he arrived home at 3883 Cartier St. about 11 p.m. Saturday, prompting his 10-year-daughter to call 911.

properties.name: Oct. 10, 2007
properties.description: Posted by VancouverpapersAddress: McDonalds at Patullo Place and Scott Road, and Surrey Memorial Hospital near King George Highway at 94th Ave. in Surrey. Victim: Dylan Krishna Becker, 38 Assailant: unknown Dylan Krishna Becker, 38, is found shot to death in the 9400-block of King George Highway in Surrey after a 911 call to the area. Police believe that, shortly before his death, Becker had been in an area near Scott Road where numerous gunshots were fired. No one has been charged with the crime.

properties.name: Oct. 19, 2007
properties.description: Posted by VancouverpapersAddress: Balmoral Tower, 1505-9830 East Whalley Ring Road, Surrey Victims: Ed Schellenberg,55 Chris Mohan, 22 Edward Sousakhone (Eddie) Narong, 22 Corey Jason Michael Lal, 21 Michael Justin Lal, 26 Ryan Bartolomeo, 19 Assailant: unknown Edward Schellenberg, 55, and Christopher Mohan, 22 (in accompanying photo) were among the six people murdered in Surrey on Oct. 19. Neither Schellenberg, a gas fireplace repairman, nor Mohan, a popular basketball fan who lived on the same apartment floor where the killings took place, had any involvement with the criminal world. The four other men had previously been charged with various offences, mainly relating to drug trafficking and weapons.

properties.name: Oct. 31, 2007
properties.description: Posted by VancouverpapersAddress: Cafe Biennho\' Vietnamese restaurant at 4884 Victoria Drive Victim: 51-yer-old Hiep Quang Do of Richmond Assailant: unknown Vancouver recorded its 17th murder of the year Wednesday when a gunman entered a Vietnamese restaurant at 4884 Victoria Drive and shot and killed a 51-year-old Richmond resident shortly after 9 p.m. The victim was known to police, Vancouver Police spokesman Const. Howard Chow said. Investigators released few details of the killing except to say that they believe it was a targeted shooting. Chow said it was too early in the investigation to say whether the murder was gang-related, or if it was a retaliation shooting.

properties.name: Seized asset: 4640 Woodburn Rd., West Vancouver
properties.description: Posted by Vancouverpapers4640 Woodburn Rd., West Vancouver, B.C.Seized asset: 4640 Woodburn Rd., West Vancouver. Reason seized: It is alleged that the co-owner of the home, Dale Alexander Prentice, has been directly involved in large-scale trafficking of marijuana and cocaine between Canada and the U.S., and he has been implicated in laundering large sums of money from criminal enterprises. Named in lawsuit: Dale Prentice and Shannon Joanne Bennett. Synopsis: The -million-plus home in Upper Caulfeild was purchased by the defendants in 2005 for 53,000. Prentice was investigated in U.S. by the Bureau of Immigration and Customs Enforcement (ICE), where he was arrested as a large-scale money smuggler. His alleged associates, Andrew Crookbain and Jason Scott Hunter, were accused of conspiracy to import marijuana, conspiracy to distribute cocaine and engaging in money laundering. A supporting affidavit filed by ICE agent Steve Cagen said Hunter was paid ,000 to drive 20,000 US from New York to Los Angeles, then drove to Seattle with 20 kilograms of cocaine. The affidavit says Crookbain is a Canadian detained in Maui last Jan. 29 as a material witness and was escorted to Seattle, where he told police Prentice was growing marijuana in Canada. Prentice entered into a guilty plea agreement with U.S. authorities and was sentenced to a nine-year prison term. Hunter got four years. Crookbain wasn’t charged in the U.S. but faces drug-related charges in Vancouver. Forfeiture proceedings are pending against the West Vancouver home.

Case synopsis: DeVries was president and sole shareholder of Amber Enterprises, which encouraged B.C. investors to put .8 million of their money with a U.S. company, which would purportedly buy inexpensive goods in bulk from overseas suppliers and sell them to major retailers such as Home Depot and Costco. Investors were promised returns of 25 to 50 per cent within three to six months, which they could donate to charity. The investment turned out to be a fraudulent Ponzi scheme. The seized money is being distributed to investors who lost money.

He was about to drop off his 14-year-old son at a high school when he noticed he was being followed by two or three men in another vehicle. He fled the scene, hitting another vehicle before losing control of his Hummer and crashing into a ditch just east of Peterson Road elementary at 23422 47th Ave. The pursuers then pulled up beside the Hummer and fired several rounds into the front and side of the vehicle.
